column12: Long short term memory; linear regression; gradient-boosted trees; dynamic time warping
column42:
Not a great paper.

The rationale for the clustering analysis is not totally clear to me.

Why do they predict NA dose at the last (not next) timestep? Unclear how this would be used to guide dosing.

Just uses current clinical practice as the gold standard, but eligible as the authors say (end of intro) that they intend to use their system to guide care.

column3: A Machine Learning Algorithm to Predict Severe Sepsis and Septic Shock: Development, Implementation, and Impact on Clinical Practice
column5: A Machine Learning Algorithm to Predict Severe Sepsis and Septic Shock: Development, Implementation, and Impact on Clinical Practice
column12: Random forest
column42:
The definition of the training cohort is confusing: how were the negative training examples defined? Confusingly it seems to be the patients who did NOT meet 'sepsis training criteria'. If this is so then, what is the relevance of sepsis onset as they have defined it (p1486 top right)

Note there are only 950 positive training patients episodes (a suspiciously low number?), and algorithm considers 587 features.

The sepsis training criteria differ slightly from the severe sepsis / septic shock definitions used during validation (e.g. the latter omits clinical codes and uses SIRS) later in the same paragraph. Septic shock definition during validation doesn't seem to require refractory hypotension, just hypotension.

Specificity is suspiciously high. Did they just pick a high threshold on the ROC curve to reduce alarm fatigue?

column3: InferNet for Delayed Reinforcement Tasks: Addressing the Temporal Credit Assignment Problem
column5: InferNet for Delayed Reinforcement Tasks: Addressing the Temporal Credit Assignment Problem
column12: Feedforward neural network, dueling deep Q network, Gaussian process
column42:
Interesting idea - do they inspect the intermediate rewards? Would be interesting to see whether they are clinically intuitive.

I can't see that intermediate rewards addresses confounding issues.

Suppose that some aspect of current treatment strategies in septic shock produce harmful medium or long term effects - e.g. we give too much fluid, impairing recovery to baseline mobility - but that we apply the misguided strategy consistently across patients, e.g. because the SSC tells us to. I can't see how InferNet would work out that this was harmful and infer a low intermediate reward for excessive fluids.
